title: Introducing the new Instagram pose: The downward gaze
text: Share 204 shares Getting creative: Shani Grimmond tried it out by casually gazing down while walking up a set of stairs and stared straight down at her feet before a night out Whimsical: Gabby Epstein also tried out the fad while on the beach Pia Muehlenbeck is also a fan of the fad and has shared countless candid snaps of herself candidly looking down - from shots in the pool to photos by the ocean. The Kardashian family is also on board the new trend, with Kylie Jenner regularly trying it out - especially during shoots. This isn't the only recurring pose to pop up on social feeds however, with the Insta Sit also a favourite of social stars around the globe. Casual: Among those to try it are Queensland gurus Shani Grimmond and Hannah Polites (pictured) as well as travel blogger Sjana Earp and model Mimi Elashiry Bronzed: A Bikini A Day's Devin Brugman has also shared her take on the trend, as well as model Elyse Knowles and social star Inka Williams (pictured) Simple: Mimi Elashiry tried out the trend while at New York Fashion Week recently Popular with bikini models and bloggers, the pose is characterised by sitting down, stretching one leg out so it sits straight and tucking the other underneath. But why are they all still rocking the Insta Sit, and what are the photographic benefits? First up, it's hugely flattering. Sitting with one leg tucked and one outstretched is an instant leg lengthener, not to mention that sitting this way will slim your limbs. Secondly, it's great for showing off a (year-round) tan. International: The Kardashian family is also on board the new trend, with Kylie Jenner (pictured) regularly trying it out - especially during shoots The Insta Sit: This isn't the only recurring pose to pop up on social feeds however, with the Insta Sit also a favourite of social stars around the globe Easy: Popular with bikini models and bloggers, the pose is characterised by sitting down, stretching one leg out so it sits straight and tucking the other under (pictured: Kirralee Morris) 'Basically, it's all about angles,' professional photographer, James Day , told Daily Mail. 'It's an angled pose, yet relaxed. There's a rule with posing that if it bends, bend it. Nearly everything in these poses looks bent, which fits the relaxed vibe. 'Standing up and posing is more reminiscent of standing on the red carpet ten years ago.' Read more: Share or comment on this article 204
